pull.title: rpc: Accept scientific notation for monetary amounts in JSON
pull.body:
Add a function `ParseFixedPoint` that parses numbers according to the JSON number specification and returns a 64-bit integer.

Then use this in `AmountFromValue`, rather than `ParseMoney`.

Also add lots of tests (thanks to @jonasschnelli for some of them).

Fixes issue #6297.

repo.name: bitcoin
repo.description: Laanwj's Bitcoin Core fork - see README.md on "readme" branch

events.body:
Tested ACK (reviewed code/tests, ran tests, successfully ran `smartfees.py`, some curl scientific notation tests).

```
jonasschnelli$ curl --user bitcoinrpc:DP6DvqZtqXarpeNWyN3LZTFchCCyCUuHwNF7E8pX99x1 --data-binary '{"jsonrpc": "1.0", "id" : "1", "method": "sendtoaddress", "params": ["myWgdwSvL2z2WxUbc7wKnRnWnbR925YDaH", 1e-4] }' http://127.0.0.1:18332
{"result":"2ebf06579a36aa8a452924a071460de05d5d87ffc9266d35190ebc42e8476bf9","error":null,"id":"1"}

...
```

ACK (code review and tested, but not exhaustively)

issue.title: rpc: Accept strings in AmountFromValue
issue.body:
Accept strings containing decimal values, in addition to bare values.

note: untested

events.body: ACK. Carefully reviewed the code, but didn't test. The included test cases are convincing.

events.message:
rpc: Accept scientific notation for monetary amounts in JSON

Add a function `ParseFixedPoint` that parses numbers according
to the JSON number specification and returns a 64-bit integer.

Then this in `AmountFromValue`, rather than `ParseMoney`.

Also add lots of tests (thanks to @jonasschnelli for some of them).

Fixes issue #6297.

issue.title: RPC doesn't accept scientific notation for amounts
issue.body:
Reported by @morcos on IRC.

Since the univalue conversion, JSON no longer accepts e.g. 1e-5 as monetary amount. This is required by the JSON standard.

![Parsing diagram numbers](https://usercontent.irccloud-cdn.com/file/Y2aSQLis/IMG_2694.GIF)

This breaks e.g. the `smartfees.py` test. This needs to be fixed in `AmountFromValue` or `ParseMoney`.

issue.title: Add UniValue as subtree
issue.body:
Cherry-picked from the following upstream PRs:

- bitcoin/bitcoin#6637
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6239
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6379
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6456
- bitcoin/bitcoin#6788

labels.name: S-waiting-on-review
labels.description: Status: Awaiting review from the assignee but also interested parties.

issue.title: rpc: Accept strings in AmountFromValue
issue.body:
Patch to accept strings containing decimal value + other fixes leading up to it in Core.

Contains these PRs:
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/5486/ - [REST] JSON support for /rest/headers
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6239/ - Don't go through double in AmountFromValue and ValueFromAmount
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6362/ - Fix null id in RPC response during startup
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6379/ - rpc: Accept scientific notation for monetary amounts in JSON
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6456/ - rpc: Avoid unnecessary parsing roundtrip in number formatting, fix locale issue
https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6380/ - rpc: Accept strings in AmountFromValue

issue.title: Base work for the Sapling signatureHash
issue.body:
Base work for the new transaction digest algorithm for signature verification on PIVX Sapling transactions.

Essentially, an implementation of BIP143 + few more good commits that found down the rabbit hole.

Back ports:

* bitcoin#7276 
* bitcoin#7976
* bitcoin#8118
* bitcoin#8149 (only amount validation and SignatureHash commits).
* bitcoin#6088 (only the dummy signature one - will be removed once #1663 get merged -).
* bitcoin#6379
* bitcoin#8524

Next step over this area (need 1553 merged to be able to push it) is the further specialization of BIP143 into our custom implementation of ZIP143 (with a different digest algorithm definition using our tx data and hash personalization).

issue.title: RPC & Mempool back ports.
issue.body:
More back ports and adaptations over the RPC values parsing and mempool. We need to get closer in this area :) .

* bitcoin#6379
* bitcoin#6715
* bitcoin#6915
* bitcoin#7007
* bitcoin#7008
* bitcoin#12643
* bitcoin#18474
* bitcoin#18704

comments.body: Isn't this a duplicate of the above line?
Yes, will remove (or if you have another test to suggest, please do :-).
maybe add some zeroes after the decimal point.  you have an excessive number before and and excessive number after, try a test with an excessive number of zeroes both before and after....
Hypernit: this comment seems inaccurate. There are definitely larger integers that fit in 64 bit.

it's worded somewhat ackwardly: my point is that larger 64-bit signed integers cannot consist of arbitrary combinations of 0-9:

```
 999999999999999999   1^18-1
9223372036854775807  (1<<63)-1 (max)
9999999999999999999  would not fit
```

Wouldn't be impossible to handle it, but I it would complicate bounds checking and don't see the point in our case.
I'll update the comment.
